repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Private Provision of
            Infrastructure Technical Assistance Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Provision of
            Infrastructure Technical Assistance (PPITA) Loan Project for
            Indonesia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: PPITA experience shows that
            creating new institutions and empowering them is much more
            difficult than anticipated in the project documents. Such
            change requires a long gestation period and a willingness to
            re-distribute power between the various institutions.
            Borrowers have been willing to borrow at International Bank
            for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) rates for program
            lending and larger project loans; however, IBRD technical
            assistance (TA) loans may not be competitive where an
            abundance of grant funds exist as is the case in Indonesia
            at present. This lesson is consistent with the experience of
            many other countries where only grants or International
            Development Association (IDA) money are accepted for TA and
            non-income-earning projects. Public Private Partnership
            (PPP) reform is enormously complex, involving many
            governmental and non-governmental entities. Donors working
            in an area such as this need to ensure that they coordinate
            closely with Government of Indonesia (GoI) and harmonize
            their agendas to avoid working across purposes.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Private Provision of
            Infrastructure Technical Assistance Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Private
            Provision of Infrastructure Technical Assistance Project for
            Indonesia is to assist the Government in developing and
            implementing the policy and regulatory reforms and build the
            institutional and social foundations needed to enable,
            promote, and facilitate efficient and sustainable
            large-scale private investment in infrastructure. There are
            three main project components. The first component,
            Cross-sectoral technical assistance and advisory services,
            encompasses: Core support to the Secretariat for the
            Committee on Policy for the Acceleration of Infrastructure
            Development (KPPI Secretariat) and Planning and Investment
            Sub-committee; supplementary support to the KPPI Secretariat
            and Planning and Investment Sub-committee; and support for
            the establishment and initial operation of a central
            Public-Private Partnership (P3) unit. With the second
            component, the largest part of the project resources will be
            allocated to sector-specific activities aimed at
            establishing conditions conducive to sustainable private
            investment in infrastructure, and to developing specific
            opportunities for such investment. The project will focus
            primarily on the transport, telecommunications, and urban
            infrastructure sectors, and support activities involving: 1)
            legal and regulatory reform (drafting of sector laws and
            implementing regulations);2)design and establishment of
            regulatory institutions; 3) conduct of sector policy and
            strategy studies with a strong PPI focus and impact
            (including sector / sub-sector privatization strategy
            studies); 4) establishment of key sectoral "nodes"
            in the national P3 network; 5) preparation and tendering of
            pilot PPI projects; and 6) conduct and dissemination of
            "lessons learned" analyses for recent private
            infrastructure projects and privatization initiatives. The
            third component The project contributes to capacity building
            and training in areas relating to private participation in infrastructure.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Private Provision of
            Infrastructure Technical Assistance Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Demonstration projects will be designed
            within the framework of the project, feasible to, and
            attractive for private investment, that would generate
            small, and medium scale infrastructure works, targeting
            mostly telecommunications, and transportation. Given these
            projects could produce environmental, and social adversity,
            these safeguards and environmental screening procedures have
            been developed, to be applied in all demonstration project
            preparation, and integrated into the bidding and contract
            documents for each selected scheme. During the initial
            screening stage, the Government shall utilize existing data
            available during project preparation, but in the absence of
            such data, site visits, and information collection will be
            undertaken by the Project Management Unit (PMU) to establish
            the data needed for screening, and approval by the Bank for
            the environmental assessment (EA) classification, as a
            condition prior to the investors' invitation to the
            bidding process. A second stage screening will require a
            detailed assessment of project characteristics, considering
            key environmental issues, e.g., scope of impacts, assessment
            boundaries, nature, and biodiversity conservation, which
            should include field studies on environmental impacts. The
            Government should provide case-by-case partial financing to
            investors for implementation of the second stage EA
            screening, and prepare draft environmental documentation, to
            determine the appropriate environmental category of a
            project, consistent with the Government, and Bank
            requirements. The local environmental authority shall
            implement periodic monitoring on environmental management,
            to be reported to the PMU. Social assessment, resettlement
            issues, and isolated vulnerable groups are covered briefly.
